subsection.name: Why do we need another workflow project?
subsection.p: The implementor and organization funding the development of werkflow felt that existing open-source solutions were insufficient for their needs in another project.

subsection.name: How are other projects insufficient?
subsection.p: Most of the other workflow projects deal directly with user-interface flows or otherwise interactive processes. While this is useful, we needed a workflow system that could also coordinate large-scale and long-term business process flows. Ideally, a single engine could address both user-interface flows and enterprise business processes.

subsection.name: Who develops werkflow?
subsection.p: werkflow is developed by the The Werken Company under contract with Zenplex. The project lead is Bob McWhirter.

subsection.name: Does werkflow conform to any standards (BPEL4WS, BPML, etc)
subsection.p: At this time, no. These standards tend to address a very small portion of the workflow space. They also tend to be block-based workflow descriptions where werkflow is based upon states and transitions.

subsection.name: What is petridish?
subsection.p: petridish is the generic petri net framework that werkflow uses to model and execute processes. It was also created by The Werken Company.
